questions.question: A 35-year-old female patient of asian ethnicity with a BMI of 34 kg/m² has decided to seeksurgical options to reduce her weight. She has multiple comorbidities. Which of the followingwould make her unsuitable for bariatric surgery?
Which of the following is not a contraindication for bariatric surgery?

options.A: Failure to lose weight despite psychotherapy

questions.explanation: Failure to lose weight by an obese patient despite psychotherapy, pharmacotherapy, and lifestylemodifications is an indication for metabolic surgery.Potential contraindications to metabolic and bariatric surgery include:•Severe medical disease making anesthesia or surgery prohibitively risky (American Society ofAnesthesiologists class IV)●Mentally incompetent to understand the procedure• Inability or unwillingness to change lifestyle postoperatively• Drug, alcohol, or other addiction (including smoking)• Active problem of bulimia or other eating disorder••Psychological instability (schizophrenia, severe depression)• Unsupportive home environment462

questions.question: A 40-year-old male patient with a BMI of 42 kg/m² with central obesity is scheduled toundergo bariatric surgery. As preparation for surgery, he is advised to follow a457low-carbohydrate, low-fat, and moderate-protein meal, for two weeks. On follow-up, he isfound to be non-compliant with the diet. What is the next best step?
questions.explanation: Psychological re-evaluation is necessary to address the underlying psychological blocks in apatient who is unable to comply with the diet.Morbidly obese individuals, especially those with central obesity, have large livers that makesurgery impossible. Liver shrinkage diet helps reduce the size of the liver. This allows mobility forthe surgeon and increases the chances of a safer procedure.Liver shrinkage diet:•Low-carbohydrate, low-fat and moderate protein diet• Started at least 2 weeks prior to the surgery463The ability to comply with the diet and lose weight suggests that the patient is willing to make aneffort to adopt lifestyle modifications. Failure to do so must arouse suspicion of importantunderlying psychological blocks, which need addressing.

questions.question: Which of the following is a reversible bariatric surgery?
questions.explanation: Laparoscopic gastric banding and intra-gastric balloon placement surgeries are considered to bereversible bariatric surgeries.It is because the gastric band or the intragastric balloon can be removed once the desired weightloss or metabolic benefit is achieved.Virtual stomachpouch.Adjustable bandGastric BandingPort used to adjust thesize of the band.OMARROW464An inflatable band is placed just below the GE junction↓A small virtual stomach pouch is created↓Reduces hunger (probably vagally mediated)↓Reduced consumption of food↓Weight lossComplications of LAGB include:•Prolapse / Slippage (most common)•• Band erosion of the stomach wall and rupture•Increased risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism (highest risk within 1 month of surgery),managed with early ambulation, pressure stockings and LMWH.

questions.question: In recent years, what is the most commonly performed bariatric surgery?
questions.explanation: Sleeve gastrectomy is the most commonly performed bariatric surgery, in recent years.Sleeve GastrectomyGastric sleevePylorusOMARROWResectedstomachA vertical sleeve is created, resecting most of the greater curvature↓↓Restriction of stomach capacity465Early satiety↓Reduced consumption of food↓Weight lossAdvantages of sleeve gastrectomy:• Less challenging procedure•• Preservation of pylorus (avoids gastric dumping)•No need for serial adjustments (as seen with gastric banding)• Reduction in internal hernias (as seen with Roux-en-Y gastric bypass)Complications of sleeve gastrectomy:• Bleed from the staple line• Leakage from staple line (close to the angle of His)

questions.question: 458A 40-year-old woman with diabetes and a BMI of 46 kg/m² underwent laparoscopic sleevegastrectomy (LSG). On the second postoperative day, she developed fever, tachycardia, andblood reports show leucocytosis. What is the next best step in her management?

options.A: Send blood for culture and sensitivity
options.B: USG abdomen to locate the septic focus

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of fever, tachycardia, and leucocytosis in a postoperative patient ofLSG should raise suspicion for leak along the gastric staple line. The next best step in themanagement of this patient is to perform a contrast-enhanced CT.Leaks following LSG most commonly occur in the proximal third of the stomach, close to theangle of His. Early leaks are due to tissue trauma and staple misfire, and late leaks are usually dueto ischemia and high intragastric pressure.Management of the leak involves providing nutritional support to the patient and adequatedrainage. Once the leak is diagnosed, the patient should be kept nil per oral.Total parenteral nutrition and antibiotic therapy should be started in the patient. Drainage can bedone either by CT-guided percutaneous catheter placement, endoscopic stenting, or operativeprocedures.Note: Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a risk factor for an anastomotic leak. Treatment withcontinuous positive airway pressure might reduce this risk.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding Roux-en-Y gastric bypass in bariatricsurgery?

options.A: Gastric pouch is created at the lesser curvature.
options.B: Biliary limb is 100-150 cm in length
options.C: It is a purely restrictive type of procedure.

questions.explanation: Gastric pouch is created at the lesser curvature in Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.466The Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass SurgeryDuodenumJejunumBypassedportion of stomachGastric pouch-JejunumBypassedduodenumFoodDigestive juiceOMARROWA small proximal gastric pouch is created at the lesser curvature↓Create a shorter biliary limb of 30 - 50 cm (duodenum);Create a longer Roux limb of 75 - 150 cm (jejunum)↓Bowel continuity is restored by a Y - jejunojejunostomy↓Restrictive + Malabsorptive mechanism↓Weight lossNote:Biliary limb is usually kept short (30-50 cm) in order to reduce vitamin and mineral deficiencies.

questions.question: A 38-year-old woman presented to the casualty with vomiting and severe colicky pain in theabdomen for the past 48 hours. She had undergone a weight reduction surgery six monthsago and had achieved around 30% weight loss. Her plain X-ray abdomen is given below.Which of the following bariatric procedures was most likely done in this patient?459
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and radiograph (dilated bowel segments with valvulae conniventes inthe left upper quadrant) are suggestive of small bowel obstruction. Bariatric surgery, specifically,Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery is associated with the creation of mesenteric defects. The smallbowel can herniate through these defects (internal hernia) and get strangulated, resulting in bowelobstruction.In addition, as the person loses weight (due to the bariatric procedure), the protective,space-occupying effect of the mesenteric fat is lost and hernia spaces open up, further increasingthe risk of internal hernia. The laparoscopic procedure has a higher risk compared to opensurgery since fewer adhesions form to tether small-bowel loops and prevent them from467herniating.Adequate closure of the mesenteric defects by the surgeon at the time of operation significantlyreduces the risk of internal hernia.Other complications specific to Roux-en-Y gastric bypass:• Nutritional deficiencies: iron (most common), folate, Vitamin A, D, K and B12• Anastomosis site leak•Bleeding from the site of gastrojejunostomy• Dumping syndrome• Marginal ulcers•• Increased risk of DVT and pulmonary embolismOption A: Sleeve gastrectomy is often complicated by staple line leak.Option B: Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding is associated with band slippage and erosion.Option D: Endoluminal stapling is also used to create a gastric sleeve. It is associated withpostoperative nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and transient dysphagia.

questions.question: A patient who previously underwent biliopancreatic diversion surgery has been havingexcessive malabsorption and is now being planned for a revisional procedure to increase thelength of the common channel. What is the usual length of the common channel?
questions.explanation: The usual length of the common channel in biliopancreatic diversion (BPD) is 50 cm (0.5 m).Revisions increase common channel by up to 150 cm.The length of the common channel plays a significant role in the amount of weight loss achievedwith BPD procedure. A shorter common channel implies a greater length of the bypassed smallbowel. This induces more malabsorption and thereby greater weight loss.Biliopancreatic diversion (BPD)Biliary limbFoodAlimentarylimb 2.0 mCommon channel 0.5 mOMARROWDigestive juiceDistal hemigastrectomy is performed to create a residual gastric pouch↓468Terminal ileum is divided 250 cm proximal to the ileocecal valve↓Gastroileostomy: Proximal anastomosis between the distal end of divided ileum and residualgastric pouch↓Ileoileostomy: Distal anastomosis between the proximal end of divided ileum and terminal ileum↓A common channel of 50 cm is established↓Malabsorption↓Weight lossProphylactic cholecystectomy is usually performed since there is an increased incidence ofgallstones due to malabsorption of bile salts.Complications of biliopancreatic diversion surgery:• Anastomosis site leak• Nutritional deficiencies: Iron; folate; vitamins A, D, K, and B12.Marginal ulcers• Bleeding•• Increased risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism (maximum risk within 1 month of surgery),managed with early ambulation, pressure stocking, and LMWH

questions.question: What is the most common cause of death in patients who undergo bariatric surgery?
questions.explanation: Pulmonary embolism is the most common cause of death in patients of bariatric surgery.Pathogenesis:Obesity↓Increased levels of plasminogen activator inhibitor-1↓Blocks conversion of plasminogen to plasmin↓Decreased fibrinolytic activity↓↓Hypercoagulable stateIncreased risk for VTEMorbidly obese patients are physically inactive. Restricted mobility post-surgery potentiates thisrisk of developing deep vein thrombosis.
